story:
I grew up in the city, but my parents grew a vegetable garden in our backyard. They gave me my own little plot where I planted pink and purple flowers, and they let me keep a couple of rabbits too. Since I was a little girl, I have always loved digging in the dirt, helping plants grow, and caring for animals. My Dad saved this picture I that drew when I was about eight; it depicts my childhood vision for my future farm. 

Flash forward 30 years ... my boyfriend Chris and I cultivated a mini-farm in our rented duplex. We built a 20x4 foot garden bed and a greenhouse for vegetables and herbs in the backyard. We raised five chickens that lay over two dozen eggs every week (we haven't bought eggs in over a year, plus they make the best organic fertilizer you've ever seen). We have a worm composting system, and we recently added five colonies of honey bees. Our mini-farm is completely sustainable. We designed closed loops for organic matter, with each component feeding the next component in an infinite cycle.

We make our own jam, jelly, pickles, cheese, beer, and lots of other things from scratch -- and we love to share what we make with our friends and family. So many people asked to buy what we produce that we decided to start a business, Valhalla Organics, to sell our farm-to-table goodies to the public. 

With the launch of Valhalla Organics, we intend to engage a larger community who support sustainable farming and beekeeping as a means to reinvent our food systems and revolutionize our world. But launching a new business isn't even the most exciting news we have to share... 

After searching forever to find the perfect place, we recently purchased five and a half acres of rural land in Southern Oregon.

Our land is a secluded evergreen forest, with towering Ponderosa pine trees surrounding perfect natural clearings. It's completely off-grid and there's nothing on the property except an outhouse (miraculously in pristine condition). The land backs up to over two million acres of wilderness, so the bees will have plenty of space to forage. 

We don't plan to live there full-time right away, but we do need to make the land "livable" so that we can care for the crops and bees during the growing season. 

Our dream is coming true -- but it's going to take a lot of work to get everything ready for bees and plants (and people!). That's why we are reaching out to our community for help launching this small farm. 

What We Need 

Of course, there are a million projects and plenty of costs associated with starting a small farm business. Each project isn't terribly expensive on its own, but they all add up to a total estimated infrastructure/start-up cost of $15,850.  

We're not asking for help with *all* of the expenses, so we set our fundraising goal much lower than the total cost that we expect to pay to set up the land.

Of course we'll be thrilled if we meet or exceed our goal, but really we are just hoping for a small financial boost as a vote of confidence from our friends to get this farm started. We are grateful for your generosity. Every contribution -- no matter how large or how small -- helps us make this happen.

Fall Priorities

There are four crucial projects that must be completed before the snow starts falling and the ground freezes. During winter, two to six feet of snow cover is typical at our elevation, and it can start snowing as early as October. The dirt road to our land isn't plowed, so it will be inaccessible once snow accumulates, making these projects urgent to complete. Fall expense total = $6,200. 

  1. Driveway: The driveway needs some work so vehicles can safely make it down (and more importantly, back up again!). The plan is to put a layer of cinder down to smooth it out, and there may be a bit of excavation involved (there are a few large rocks). Estimated cost: $500
  2. Water: There is no water on the property, so we will install two in-ground water tanks (it's important to have two in case one fails). We'll hire a water delivery truck to fill the tanks in the spring. This system will provide all the water we need to drink and bathe, with enough to water the plants (they need a lot more than we do) and to provide water for the bees (they need water to drink and to keep their hives cool!). Estimated cost: $1800 ($1400 for two tanks; $400 for excavation.
  3. Trees: A few of the trees are hopelessly infested by bark beetles (a.k.a. "pine beetles") -- the beetles kill the trees they live in and then move on to the next tree. In order to protect the healthy trees, we need to cut down the sick trees. It's sad - but not as tragic as it would be to lose all of the trees if we let the beetles go unchecked. Luckily Chris is a certified sawyer (trained and certified to safely cut down trees), so the only thing we need is a chainsaw. Unfortunately, pine beetles love to attack the biggest, oldest trees, so it will take a pretty hardcore chainsaw to handle those massive trees. Though the beetles kill the trees they infest, the lumber is still good, so we will use it to build structures on the land. We will plant two beetle-resistant trees for every tree that we have to cut. Right now it looks like about a dozen trees need to go, so we'll plant roughly 25 new trees. Check out the perks if you're interested in sponsoring one of our baby trees! Estimated cost: $650 ($400 for the chainsaw; $250 for 25 baby trees; plus additional $1000 for 5 larger Douglas Fir trees). 
  4. Security: We need to install a proper gate for the entrance/driveway and put fencing along the property lines to make the farm more secure. In order to ensure that we put the fence in exactly the right place, we'll get an official survey of the property lines (it's expensive but necessary). We're also putting up "No Trespassing," "No Hunting," and "Caution: Bees" signs to deter unwanted visitors in the meantime.  Estimated cost: $3250 ($2500 for the fence; $250 for the gate; $500 for the survey). 

Exciting Update!

Thanks to your generosity, we bought a chainsaw that will allow us safely take down the trees. We named her "Lt. Ripley" (yes, after Sigourney Weaver's character in the "Aliens" movies), because she's a badass -- and she'll cut you!

 

Spring Priorities

As soon as the snow melts, we'll start building the infrastructure. These are just a few of the things we'll need to do before we can plant the garden and move the bees to their new home. Spring expense total = $9,650. 

  1. Housing: We plan to purchase a used trailer that we'll live in when we're up at the farm. It will undoubtedly be previously-owned, rustic, and require some work to make it livable. We hope to find a "fixer-upper" this fall so that Chris can work on it over the winter. Once we move the trailer to the land, we will build a simple three-walled shelter to protect the trailer (old trailers typically have leaky roofs), and add a simple water catchment system on the shelter roof to collect rain water. Estimated cost: $2300 ($2000 for the trailer; $300 for the shelter and water catchment system). 
  2. Power: We plan to purchase a generator and two solar panels. The generator will provide a back up power source; we may get enough sunshine to power everything we need off of solar alone but we don't want to chance it. Estimated cost: $850 ($350 for the generator; $500 for the solar panels). 
  3. Greenhouses: We will build two large greenhouses, using a hoop house design. They will be made from PVC pipe with rebar/concrete foundation and plastic sheeting for the covers. This is one of the most cost-effective and energy-efficient ways to build greenhouses, with each costing roughly $500. There is a perfect clearing that gets full sun throughout the day and is relatively flat, so we won't have to do heavy excavation to build the greenhouses. Estimated cost: $1000 for 2 greenhouses.
  4. Apiary: I plan to purchase more bees and more beehives to expand the apiary in the spring; I'd like to put at least 10 hives on the land and keep 2 hives in town. It costs about $500 to set up each hive (including the bees, the hive boxes, and what I'll need to feed them for the first 2 months). Estimated cost: $5000 for 10 new bee hives.  
  5. Bear-Proof Solar Electric Fence. What do bears like best? HONEY! There are black bears living on the land, so we need to take additional precautions to protect the hives that are not needed in town. We plan to surround all of the hives with electric fence -- and because we're off-grid, it will be a solar-powered electric fence. Our worm compost bins will also reside within the perimeter of the electric fence. Added bonus: bees, worms, and valuable compost will be protected from raccoons, skunks, foxes, and other curious/hungry animals. Estimated cost: $500.
Learn more about our apiary expansion and join Ruby to virtually walk through the land as she scopes out the best spot for the bees to live!!
 

Why Does This Matter? 

This isn't just about launching one small farm - your contribution does more than just help us personally. We wanted to share a bit about why we are doing this and what your contribution supports beyond just our little farm.  You are sustaining the ideals of permaculture, local farming, natural pollination, and organic food production when you support Valhalla Organics.

Big agriculture ("Big Ag") causes problems for everyone because they use unsustainable methods of mass food production that prioritize only profit. Because of these practices, we end up with plants and animals dominating the food supply that are genetically modified, hybridized, sterilized, or otherwise manipulated to diverge from their natural form. In addition, Big Ag poisons our food and water supplies with indiscriminate applications of pesticides, fertilizers, and dangerous chemicals known to cause harm. These corporations have created sterilized seeds, so farmers can no longer save the best seeds to germinate next season as our ancestors have been doing for millennia. They are now beholden to the company and must buy new seeds from them every year. 

Livestock fare even worse than plants in mass production -- for example, chickens have been selectively bred not to naturally copulate and not to sit on their eggs (because it's easier for commercial egg producers if the hens just lay eggs and walk away). So, thanks to Big Ag, there are only a few breeds left of heritage chickens that still know how to have sex and raise babies. It's sick and sad, and that's just one example of Big Ag destroying genetic diversity by removing natural reproduction and natural selection from the life cycle. 

The solution is to invest in sustainable farms that utilize permaculture and organic principles. That is why we grow only organic, heirloom, open-pollinated vegetables and herbs (and flowers!). We don't ever use pesticides (or any product that isn't certified organic) on our garden or with our chickens or anywhere near our bees. The vegetables you'll see at Valhalla Organics were grown sustainably from seed by our loving hands -- those heirloom seeds have been saved and passed down for generations.

The way to reclaim and rebuild our food system is to work in concert with nature instead of trying to manipulate the plants or the bees or the chickens to do our bidding.

Most food-producing plants need to be pollinated in order to produce their delicious fruits, nuts, and veggies! Unfortunately, native pollinators and honey bees are in a desperate situation -- their natural food sources and habitats are disappearing, colony collapse disorder is wreaking havoc, and the "varroa destructor" mite spreads diseases that kill colonies at an alarming rate. 

Really, it's as simple as this - if there are no pollinators, there will be not be enough food. That's why it's so important to support beekeeping and small organic farms.

Valhalla Organics prioritizes biodiversity and permaculture, applying an ecological approach to small-scale farming and food production.

When you contribute to Valhalla Organics, you are not just helping our little farm -- you're supporting sustainable farming and you're giving a boost to honey bees too. 

Perks!

We are so grateful for your support, and we created some unique perks to thank you for your generosity!

 

You can check out the full selection to the right, but here's a couple of highlights.

Your Legacy on the Land

  • Eponymous Beehive: Each of my hives has a name, and if you would like to sponsor one of my new hives... I'll name that hive whatever you'd like. Currently, my hives are named Beyoncè, Lil Kim the Queen Bee, Anya, Hammer & Sickle. 

  • Sponsor a Tree: We will plant two trees for every tree that we have to take down, and we'd like to honor you (or someone you love) by planting a tree. Each baby tree will have a small sign displaying the name of the person who sponsored it (or their chosen honoree's name). We are selecting varieties that grow well at high elevation, are drought-tolerant, and are more resistant to beetle infestation. If you'd like to sponsor multiple trees, we would love that! Indiegogo unfortunately will only let you select one "tree perk" but you can just donate the amount per tree and let us know that you want your contribution to sponsor multiple trees. We are keeping a list of everyone who sponsored trees -  we won't let technology stop you from sponsoring as many trees as you want! We have reached our capacity for the small baby seedling trees (and we look forward to honoring their sponsors when the trees go in next spring!). We've just added a new perk where you can sponsor a 5 foot tall Douglas Fir tree - we're planting five of them. 

Tasty Perks 

  • Jams, Jellies, Pickles, Relishes: Everything here is homemade and homegrown, preserved safely and infused with love! Please note that there's a shipping cost of $13 - that covers the cost of mailing you the products in a medium flat rate USPS box. Since I make everything in small batches, the quantities are limited for each item -- when the dill pickles or the cherry preserves are all claimed, they're gone! So grab your favorites before they disappear into another supporter's kitchen. 

  • Honey: My hives are just babies in the grand scheme of things, so they will need all of the honey they make this year to get through winter, so I won't take any from them. Next year, I will most likely be able to extract honey. If you choose the "Ruby's Honey" perk, you'll have to wait until next year but I promise it'll be worth the wait!

Develop Your Homesteading Skills 

A lot of our friends want to learn how to make things, grow things, and do things yourself -- so we are offering a couple of perks that will allow you to learn homesteading skills, whether or not you aspire to live off the land. 

  • Virtual Homesteading Classes: Learn how to make cheese or reload shotshells. Check out the perks for more details - these are small group sessions or 1-1 session depending on the topic of the class. Classes will be hosted via online video, so you can join from wherever you are.

  • "Choose Your Own Adventure" Homesteading Skills Phone Session: Since we can't host classes for every type of homesteading skill, but you may be interested in learning more about a specific aspect of what we do here and how to do it yourself, we are offering 30minute phone sessions. You choose the topic, and (depending on the skill you want to learn) one of us can walk you through the basics -- or we can help you troubleshoot if you're having problems with your current system. Topics could include but are not limited to: worm composting, chicken care, organic gardening, cheese making, canning, pickling, hunting, home brewing, reloading, gardening in containers/small spaces, or any of the other skills you've seen us demonstrate. We are excited to share what we've learned and help you get started. 

  • Virtual Beehive Inspection: Join me for a hive inspection via live video! This is one on one, and I only have five hives to inspect every couple of weeks so the number of spots is limited. You can ask any questions you want and (bonus!) you can laugh at me from the safety of your own home if I get stung while you're watching live. 

Risks & Challenges

Because Valhalla Organics depends on farm produce and products from the beehives, poor weather or environmental conditions outside our control could have an adverse impact.

However, we currently mitigate these factors by maintaining both an outdoor garden and a greenhouse. We have taken precautions to protect the garden, greenhouse, and the apiary from environmental hazards. Of course, no one can control the weather, but the greenhouses will provide some protection from external conditions. .

We will have greenhouses and garden beds in town and on the land next summer. I'll continue to maintain my apiary in town with just two hives (most of the bees will be on the land). 

Because of our biodiverse system and our ability to farm in two locations, Valhalla Organics will be better protected against uncontrollable environmental factors

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, but want to lend your support, THANK YOU! Here a couple ways you can help build the "buzz" about Valhalla Organics. 

Please scroll up to the top of this page and click on the HEART button to show your support on Indiegogo. 

Then use the other "share buttons" to let your friends know about our farm and our fundraising goals. You never know who will be inspired to contribute, so please share widely. You can use the buttons to share on Facebook, Twitter, email, or copy a link that you can share on any social media outlet where you connect with your people.

This is what the buttons look like -- please scroll to the top of the page to click on them:

Thank you for your support! - Ruby & Chris
story_txt:
I grew up in the city, but my parents grew a vegetable garden in our backyard. They gave me my own little plot where I planted pink and purple flowers, and they let me keep a couple of rabbits too. Since I was a little girl, I have always loved digging in the dirt, helping plants grow, and caring for animals. My Dad saved this picture I that drew when I was about eight; it depicts my childhood vision for my future farm. 

Flash forward 30 years ... my boyfriend Chris and I cultivated a mini-farm in our rented duplex. We built a 20x4 foot garden bed and a greenhouse for vegetables and herbs in the backyard. We raised five chickens that lay over two dozen eggs every week (we haven't bought eggs in over a year, plus they make the best organic fertilizer you've ever seen). We have a worm composting system, and we recently added five colonies of honey bees. Our mini-farm is completely sustainable. We designed closed loops for organic matter, with each component feeding the next component in an infinite cycle.

We make our own jam, jelly, pickles, cheese, beer, and lots of other things from scratch -- and we love to share what we make with our friends and family. So many people asked to buy what we produce that we decided to start a business, Valhalla Organics, to sell our farm-to-table goodies to the public. 
With the launch of Valhalla Organics, we intend to engage a larger community who support sustainable farming and beekeeping as a means to reinvent our food systems and revolutionize our world. But launching a new business isn't even the most exciting news we have to share... 
After searching forever to find the perfect place, we recently purchased five and a half acres of rural land in Southern Oregon. 

Our land is a secluded evergreen forest, with towering Ponderosa pine trees surrounding perfect natural clearings. It's completely off-grid and there's nothing on the property except an outhouse (miraculously in pristine condition). The land backs up to over two million acres of wilderness, so the bees will have plenty of space to forage. 
We don't plan to live there full-time right away, but we do need to make the land "livable" so that we can care for the crops and bees during the growing season. 
Our dream is coming true -- but it's going to take a lot of work to get everything ready for bees and plants (and people!). That's why we are reaching out to our community for help launching this small farm. 
What We Need 
Of course, there are a million projects and plenty of costs associated with starting a small farm business. Each project isn't terribly expensive on its own, but they all add up to a total estimated infrastructure/start-up cost of $15,850.  
We're not asking for help with *all* of the expenses, so we set our fundraising goal much lower than the total cost that we expect to pay to set up the land.
Of course we'll be thrilled if we meet or exceed our goal, but really we are just hoping for a small financial boost as a vote of confidence from our friends to get this farm started. We are grateful for your generosity. Every contribution -- no matter how large or how small -- helps us make this happen.
Fall Priorities
There are four crucial projects that must be completed before the snow starts falling and the ground freezes. During winter, two to six feet of snow cover is typical at our elevation, and it can start snowing as early as October. The dirt road to our land isn't plowed, so it will be inaccessible once snow accumulates, making these projects urgent to complete. Fall expense total = $6,200. 


Driveway: The driveway needs some work so vehicles can safely make it down (and more importantly, back up again!). The plan is to put a layer of cinder down to smooth it out, and there may be a bit of excavation involved (there are a few large rocks). Estimated cost: $500


Water: There is no water on the property, so we will install two in-ground water tanks (it's important to have two in case one fails). We'll hire a water delivery truck to fill the tanks in the spring. This system will provide all the water we need to drink and bathe, with enough to water the plants (they need a lot more than we do) and to provide water for the bees (they need water to drink and to keep their hives cool!). Estimated cost: $1800 ($1400 for two tanks; $400 for excavation.

Trees: A few of the trees are hopelessly infested by bark beetles (a.k.a. "pine beetles") -- the beetles kill the trees they live in and then move on to the next tree. In order to protect the healthy trees, we need to cut down the sick trees. It's sad - but not as tragic as it would be to lose all of the trees if we let the beetles go unchecked. Luckily Chris is a certified sawyer (trained and certified to safely cut down trees), so the only thing we need is a chainsaw. Unfortunately, pine beetles love to attack the biggest, oldest trees, so it will take a pretty hardcore chainsaw to handle those massive trees. Though the beetles kill the trees they infest, the lumber is still good, so we will use it to build structures on the land. We will plant two beetle-resistant trees for every tree that we have to cut. Right now it looks like about a dozen trees need to go, so we'll plant roughly 25 new trees. Check out the perks if you're interested in sponsoring one of our baby trees! Estimated cost: $650 ($400 for the chainsaw; $250 for 25 baby trees; plus additional $1000 for 5 larger Douglas Fir trees). 

Security: We need to install a proper gate for the entrance/driveway and put fencing along the property lines to make the farm more secure. In order to ensure that we put the fence in exactly the right place, we'll get an official survey of the property lines (it's expensive but necessary). We're also putting up "No Trespassing," "No Hunting," and "Caution: Bees" signs to deter unwanted visitors in the meantime.  Estimated cost: $3250 ($2500 for the fence; $250 for the gate; $500 for the survey). 


Exciting Update! 
Thanks to your generosity, we bought a chainsaw that will allow us safely take down the trees. We named her "Lt. Ripley" (yes, after Sigourney Weaver's character in the "Aliens" movies), because she's a badass -- and she'll cut you!

 
Spring Priorities
As soon as the snow melts, we'll start building the infrastructure. These are just a few of the things we'll need to do before we can plant the garden and move the bees to their new home. Spring expense total = $9,650. 


Housing: We plan to purchase a used trailer that we'll live in when we're up at the farm. It will undoubtedly be previously-owned, rustic, and require some work to make it livable. We hope to find a "fixer-upper" this fall so that Chris can work on it over the winter. Once we move the trailer to the land, we will build a simple three-walled shelter to protect the trailer (old trailers typically have leaky roofs), and add a simple water catchment system on the shelter roof to collect rain water. Estimated cost: $2300 ($2000 for the trailer; $300 for the shelter and water catchment system). 

Power: We plan to purchase a generator and two solar panels. The generator will provide a back up power source; we may get enough sunshine to power everything we need off of solar alone but we don't want to chance it. Estimated cost: $850 ($350 for the generator; $500 for the solar panels). 

Greenhouses: We will build two large greenhouses, using a hoop house design. They will be made from PVC pipe with rebar/concrete foundation and plastic sheeting for the covers. This is one of the most cost-effective and energy-efficient ways to build greenhouses, with each costing roughly $500. There is a perfect clearing that gets full sun throughout the day and is relatively flat, so we won't have to do heavy excavation to build the greenhouses. Estimated cost: $1000 for 2 greenhouses.


Apiary: I plan to purchase more bees and more beehives to expand the apiary in the spring; I'd like to put at least 10 hives on the land and keep 2 hives in town. It costs about $500 to set up each hive (including the bees, the hive boxes, and what I'll need to feed them for the first 2 months). Estimated cost: $5000 for 10 new bee hives.  


Bear-Proof Solar Electric Fence. What do bears like best? HONEY! There are black bears living on the land, so we need to take additional precautions to protect the hives that are not needed in town. We plan to surround all of the hives with electric fence -- and because we're off-grid, it will be a solar-powered electric fence. Our worm compost bins will also reside within the perimeter of the electric fence. Added bonus: bees, worms, and valuable compost will be protected from raccoons, skunks, foxes, and other curious/hungry animals. Estimated cost: $500.


Learn more about our apiary expansion and join Ruby to virtually walk through the land as she scopes out the best spot for the bees to live!!

 
Why Does This Matter? 
This isn't just about launching one small farm - your contribution does more than just help us personally. We wanted to share a bit about why we are doing this and what your contribution supports beyond just our little farm.  You are sustaining the ideals of permaculture, local farming, natural pollination, and organic food production when you support Valhalla Organics.

Big agriculture ("Big Ag") causes problems for everyone because they use unsustainable methods of mass food production that prioritize only profit. Because of these practices, we end up with plants and animals dominating the food supply that are genetically modified, hybridized, sterilized, or otherwise manipulated to diverge from their natural form. In addition, Big Ag poisons our food and water supplies with indiscriminate applications of pesticides, fertilizers, and dangerous chemicals known to cause harm. These corporations have created sterilized seeds, so farmers can no longer save the best seeds to germinate next season as our ancestors have been doing for millennia. They are now beholden to the company and must buy new seeds from them every year. 
Livestock fare even worse than plants in mass production -- for example, chickens have been selectively bred not to naturally copulate and not to sit on their eggs (because it's easier for commercial egg producers if the hens just lay eggs and walk away). So, thanks to Big Ag, there are only a few breeds left of heritage chickens that still know how to have sex and raise babies. It's sick and sad, and that's just one example of Big Ag destroying genetic diversity by removing natural reproduction and natural selection from the life cycle. 
The solution is to invest in sustainable farms that utilize permaculture and organic principles. That is why we grow only organic, heirloom, open-pollinated vegetables and herbs (and flowers!). We don't ever use pesticides (or any product that isn't certified organic) on our garden or with our chickens or anywhere near our bees. The vegetables you'll see at Valhalla Organics were grown sustainably from seed by our loving hands -- those heirloom seeds have been saved and passed down for generations.
The way to reclaim and rebuild our food system is to work in concert with nature instead of trying to manipulate the plants or the bees or the chickens to do our bidding.


Most food-producing plants need to be pollinated in order to produce their delicious fruits, nuts, and veggies! Unfortunately, native pollinators and honey bees are in a desperate situation -- their natural food sources and habitats are disappearing, colony collapse disorder is wreaking havoc, and the "varroa destructor" mite spreads diseases that kill colonies at an alarming rate. 
Really, it's as simple as this - if there are no pollinators, there will be not be enough food. That's why it's so important to support beekeeping and small organic farms.

Valhalla Organics prioritizes biodiversity and permaculture, applying an ecological approach to small-scale farming and food production. 
When you contribute to Valhalla Organics, you are not just helping our little farm -- you're supporting sustainable farming and you're giving a boost to honey bees too. 


Perks!
We are so grateful for your support, and we created some unique perks to thank you for your generosity!


 

You can check out the full selection to the right, but here's a couple of highlights.
Your Legacy on the Land

Eponymous Beehive: Each of my hives has a name, and if you would like to sponsor one of my new hives... I'll name that hive whatever you'd like. Currently, my hives are named Beyoncè, Lil Kim the Queen Bee, Anya, Hammer & Sickle. 
Sponsor a Tree: We will plant two trees for every tree that we have to take down, and we'd like to honor you (or someone you love) by planting a tree. Each baby tree will have a small sign displaying the name of the person who sponsored it (or their chosen honoree's name). We are selecting varieties that grow well at high elevation, are drought-tolerant, and are more resistant to beetle infestation. If you'd like to sponsor multiple trees, we would love that! Indiegogo unfortunately will only let you select one "tree perk" but you can just donate the amount per tree and let us know that you want your contribution to sponsor multiple trees. We are keeping a list of everyone who sponsored trees -  we won't let technology stop you from sponsoring as many trees as you want! We have reached our capacity for the small baby seedling trees (and we look forward to honoring their sponsors when the trees go in next spring!). We've just added a new perk where you can sponsor a 5 foot tall Douglas Fir tree - we're planting five of them. 

Tasty Perks 

Jams, Jellies, Pickles, Relishes: Everything here is homemade and homegrown, preserved safely and infused with love! Please note that there's a shipping cost of $13 - that covers the cost of mailing you the products in a medium flat rate USPS box. Since I make everything in small batches, the quantities are limited for each item -- when the dill pickles or the cherry preserves are all claimed, they're gone! So grab your favorites before they disappear into another supporter's kitchen. 
Honey: My hives are just babies in the grand scheme of things, so they will need all of the honey they make this year to get through winter, so I won't take any from them. Next year, I will most likely be able to extract honey. If you choose the "Ruby's Honey" perk, you'll have to wait until next year but I promise it'll be worth the wait!

Develop Your Homesteading Skills 
A lot of our friends want to learn how to make things, grow things, and do things yourself -- so we are offering a couple of perks that will allow you to learn homesteading skills, whether or not you aspire to live off the land. 

Virtual Homesteading Classes: Learn how to make cheese or reload shotshells. Check out the perks for more details - these are small group sessions or 1-1 session depending on the topic of the class. Classes will be hosted via online video, so you can join from wherever you are.
"Choose Your Own Adventure" Homesteading Skills Phone Session: Since we can't host classes for every type of homesteading skill, but you may be interested in learning more about a specific aspect of what we do here and how to do it yourself, we are offering 30minute phone sessions. You choose the topic, and (depending on the skill you want to learn) one of us can walk you through the basics -- or we can help you troubleshoot if you're having problems with your current system. Topics could include but are not limited to: worm composting, chicken care, organic gardening, cheese making, canning, pickling, hunting, home brewing, reloading, gardening in containers/small spaces, or any of the other skills you've seen us demonstrate. We are excited to share what we've learned and help you get started. 
Virtual Beehive Inspection: Join me for a hive inspection via live video! This is one on one, and I only have five hives to inspect every couple of weeks so the number of spots is limited. You can ask any questions you want and (bonus!) you can laugh at me from the safety of your own home if I get stung while you're watching live.

However, we currently mitigate these factors by maintaining both an outdoor garden and a greenhouse. We have taken precautions to protect the garden, greenhouse, and the apiary from environmental hazards. Of course, no one can control the weather, but the greenhouses will provide some protection from external conditions. .


We will have greenhouses and garden beds in town and on the land next summer. I'll continue to maintain my apiary in town with just two hives (most of the bees will be on the land). 
Because of our biodiverse system and our ability to farm in two locations, Valhalla Organics will be better protected against uncontrollable environmental factors

story:
Short Summary

Hello everyone! I am Crystal Cameron-Schaad, owner and sommelier of Crystal Palate. My business has  been providing wine consulting and private event services since the fall of 2013 and we are thrilled to embark on the next phase of this business with our very own retail and education space. I have an existing customer base and extensive knowledge in marketing, social media and public relations that will contribute to the great success of this neighborhood wine shop and regional education center located in Norfolk, Virginia. I am also excited to partner with my friend Nicole Abiouness, owner and winemaker for Abiouness Wines out of Napa. The shop will serve as an East Coast tasting room and event space for Abiouness Wines.

We need your support to help make our vision a reality! We are all about wine education at Crystal Palate. We want to bring civility back one sip at a time. Whether you are a novice, an oenophile or hospitality professional, Crystal Palate will help take your wine knowledge to the next level through wine tastings, immersive wine classes, professional wine courses and our meet the winemaker series.  I look forward to serving as your personal sommelier providing outstanding customer service to help you select the perfect bottle for every meal and every occasion. We will offer a quarterly wine club, wine & gourmet CSA, special case pricing and delivery services.

About Crystal Cameron-Schaad, Owner of Crystal Palate

Crystal is an award-winning journalist who spent more than a decade working in the broadcast industry as an anchor and reporter before pursuing her passion for the fruit of the vine.  She is a certified sommelier and is currently working on her Diploma certification with the Wine Spirit and Education Trust (WSET). Crystal is scheduled to finish this prestigious international program in January 2018.  Once she completes that program, she looks forward to pursuing her Master of Wine (MW) certification with the Institute of Masters of Wine out of London, England.

Crystal is a member of the Guild of Sommeliers and the Society of Wine Educators

Crystal looks forward to obtaining an Approved Programme Provider (APP) license from the Wine, Spirit and Education Trust (WSET) out of London in 2018 to teach the prestigious WSET courses. The WSET is a gold standard in the industry. Crystal Palate will also offer service training and wine etiquette classes for the hospitality industry across Coastal Virginia and beyond.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We are looking to raise $30,000 in the next 30 days to help off-set some of the capital costs of opening our shop. This is a little less than half of our start-up costs. This money will go toward building out our small gourmet kitchen, a custom tasting bar and inventory. 
  • We have some incredible rewards for our sponsors including personalized engraved tasting glasses for your use at the shop, canvas wine bags, premium memberships and a private wine tasting experience for up to 12 guests. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Thank you so much for taking the time to learn more about our vision, we would be honored if you would share this campaign with your friends, family and colleagues.

story:
A BAR WITH NO EQUAL, Fourpoints is the next generation of healthy bars and our secret ingredient is something no other bar has!
Our Motivation:

FUEL BETTER - PLAY LONGER!  That was our goal sparked from an untimely energy crash while descending a 14,000 ft. peak in the Colorado Mountains. We created Fourpoints Bar out of our passion for outdoor recreation and clean eating, and inspired by our family's fight with diabetes.

As wilderness athletes and sports nutritionists, we began to experiment with different foods & recipes in an effort to craft the ultimate nutritionally complete bar that would better support our active lifestyles and a healthier blood sugar.  Uniquely powered by prunes, Fourpoints bars are low-glycemic providing long lasting satiety and slow-burning energy without the crash.  Fourpoints is the next generation of health & wellness bars.  Innovative, creative, delicious.  Fueling you better, so you can play longer..wherever you play!




Our bars give back!

A bar isn't just a bar to us, it's an opportunity to make an impact.  We share a deep love of those wild & beautiful places and a calling to protect where we play.  As a 1% For the Planet business member, we've partnered with a select group of conservation non-profits to PROTECT public lands, PRESERVE wilderness areas & resources, PROMOTE an outdoor lifestyle and ethnic diversity in the outdoors, and to get outside and PLAY!  



 

A new mission!

We also believe in supporting those who protect us. Introducing Fourpoints Tactical; a new line of Fourpoints Bars designed specifically for our Nation's super heroes.  This high calorie, high protein meal on the go provides the highest quality nutritional support they deserve.  For this line we've collaborated and partnered with a veteran-owned organization called Troopster, who curates quality care packages for our brave men and women overseas.  


 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your support to expand both our online presence and market to new retail chains across the country.  

  • We require about $15,000 funding to expand our reach to more people nationwide.
  • We have designed an extensive list of perks for you that come with exclusive benefits!


The Impact

We wear our non-profits on our sleeves...

  • At Fourpoints we believe in interaction before transaction, collaboration over competition, and the planet and people over profit. We are a team of dedicated and passionate individuals who believe a good business does good!
  • In addition to making an impact in health by providing clean and delicious nutrition, we stand with our community whenever it needs us. 
  • By supporting us, you're helping us grow our platform to do more. 
  • The world is in a health crisis, and doctors and nurses on the front lines of this pandemic are risking their lives every day in this fight.  We've donated bars and PPE supplies to Denver area hospitals and with our partners at Troopster we've sent out care packages to front-line medical personnel across the country.

 


Risks & Challenges
 

COVID-19 changed everything.  Not just for us, for everyone!  Markets changed, consumer buying habits changed, supply chains became disrupted, and retailers shut their doors.  Everything we built vanished in a nanosecond.  Our immediate risk and challenges include: 

  • Broadening our reach online and gaining more customers. 
  • Retailers are facing uncertainties as much as suppliers are.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We hope that you will support us, it can be in any way, even as little as sharing this cause. It will mean the world to us!

  • Please share our campaign with your family and friends and let's spread this goodness together!

Risks & Challenges 
COVID-19 changed everything.  Not just for us, for everyone!  Markets changed, consumer buying habits changed, supply chains became disrupted, and retailers shut their doors.  Everything we built vanished in a nanosecond.  Our immediate risk and challenges include: 

Broadening our reach online and gaining more customers. 
Retailers are facing uncertainties as much as suppliers are.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help
We hope that you will support us, it can be in any way, even as little as sharing this cause. It will mean the world to us!
Please share our campaign with your family and friends and let's spread this goodness together!

story:
SALMON JERKY: JBC JERKY LOOKING FOR START-UP CAPITAL TO PRODUCE OUR SUPERFOOD!           

 

Bio

We Best Callibress are proud to inform that we are manufacturer, distributor & retailer of Our new fast-growing brand JBC Premium Jerky. We have been in the seafood business for over a decade and have many years of experience in processing fishes. Salmon was the most popular fish for our customers and also loved by us.  and the reason is obvious: we like healthy food and jerky is our favorite snack hence, we decided to create healthy salmon jerky as a snack because the jerky on the market could be also delicious but it's only smoked some of them ground and preserved a lot of salt, which is not a healthy way of processing.  That's why we came up with the idea of ​​how to make salmon jerky in a healthy way.  We use the dehumidification process and only organic ingredients.  Our unique process maintains the natural color of salmon, locked all benefits in each piece of jerky, and are easy to chew.  just the right delicious snack.

  • NOT SMOKED 
  • NOT GROUND 
  • NOT ARTIFICIAL FLAVORS 
  • NOT PRESERVED WITH SALT

Where do we stand now?

With an idea, to table work & all tests of the product, to build a production plant, JBC salmon jerky has passed all the processes required to launch a Brand, and Now ready for the market. We already have a production plant, packing unit, marketing team & everything one may need to give life to a brand.

Our Highlights

  • FDA Approval
  • 10.000 Sf size production plant, with 6 sections 
  • Great reach on the online marketplace
  • A team of Professionals
 

What do we need?

We believe in multiplication and we believe in expansion. We already have our products ready to launch but we need your support to make our Jerky make that happen. We want your support for fulfilling our supplier’s demand, increasing production, adding more sizes & flavors.

 

We already have some international demand and orders for our products but Covid19 has impacted our business hence we weren’t able to fulfill that. We are confident that with your support we can increase the production to fulfill all our orders and take this initiative to new horizons.

 

Why should you invest in us?

Huge Demand

Covid19 has changed millions of lives and taught us many lessons for life. We have seen that the demand for a sustainable and healthy food diet has been significantly increased. We believe that a big crisis brings big opportunities for those who want to grab that and this is the time when you should grab this right opportunity to get better returning revenue.

Every Green Business

Grocery & Gourmet Food business modules are eternal. Even in the toughest time, food businesses have always grown compared to other businesses hence we are positive that our business would bring good fruit to your investment.

Futuristic business module

We have many future strategies and plans to take this business to new milestones, As we said we already started receiving demands from other parts of the globe and once we are all set with the US market, we would not wait to grab global opportunities to enhance profit on your investment and bring you a great return on your investment.

 

How are we different?

We proudly acknowledge that our secret method of crafting premium extra delicious jerky is all about unique processes & we prefer health over everything without forgetting that our customers want the mouthwatering gourmet snacks. We not only claim to offer healthy food with great taste but also have FDA proof that our Presentation of making turning Salmon to Jerky is a unique process. Which is healthier than others and makes it a finger-licking snack for everyone. Using high-quality Atlantic salmon, our jerky is perfect for a nutrient-rich snack or an on-the-go bite.

 

Our Jerky: We operate in the highest quality and speed from creation, to production, to delivery, all the way to customer service. Our devotion to the product comes from the unconditional love we put in. With lean protein, Omega 3, Omega 6, and Omega 9 fatty acids, our jerky provides many of the nutrients necessary for a healthy diet.

         

The Salmon

Raised naturally in the cold North Atlantic waters of New Brunswick and Newfoundland, the salmon is sold fresh only and transported by truck. The only way to obtain fresh Atlantic salmon is through salmon farming operations, which provides year-round work in communities where typically only seasonal employment is available. The Canadian Aquaculture industry is one of the most regulated industries in the world (governed by a framework that includes 73 pieces of federal and provincial legislation), so you know that the product is of the highest quality.

The Nutrition Facts

1. OMEGA OILS 3 (1.9 grams)

2. OMEGA OILS 6 (3.6 grams)

3. OMEGA OILS 9 (8. grams)

One serving of salmon contains 4 g of total fat (0.9 g saturated fat, 1.5 g monounsaturated fat, 2.1 g polyunsaturated fat).

 

Last but not least

We love the ocean and we believe in giving back. We have decided to help organizations working for the sake of the Ocean. We encourage & support ocean cleaning projects.

-------------------- ----------------------- A note from the CEO------------------------------------------------

We know that these are difficult times for everyone. With the current COVID-19 crisis, many of us are more aware of our health than ever. With our jerky, you know that you are providing your body with essential vitamins and minerals. The high protein content and number of nutrients in our jerky make it a superfood, and its shelf life of ten months means that it is a perfect choice for stocking up on healthy snacks.

story:
THE MOST IMPORTANT PART!!

After almost 2 years of searching for the right spot, we have found one! We passed the tenant application process and are about to sign a lease. The main problem is that the location needs a complete kitchen build out. We met with the SBA and are in the process of receiving a small business loan. Our kitchen build out is estimated to cost us about $85,000.00.  The bank takes 45-60 days to process our loan application, which is tough when we have already found the perfect spot. In order to secure the location and to begin building out right away, we need to raise a decent chunk of cash quickly. 

 

About Us

The thing I am most passionate about in life is being a voice for the voiceless, and putting a stop to animal cruelty. The second thing I am most passionate about are desserts, and being a vegan baker is the best of both worlds. My name is Meghan, and I am the creator of Miss Vegan. 

Miss Vegan is plant based bakery based out of Rhode Island, but also serves parts of MA & CT. We create magical desserts that are free from animal products, byproducts, and artificial dyes. We also make some items that are free of soy, gluten. and nuts. You can currently find us at local events/pop- ups or by placing a custom order. Things have been going so well that we have out grown our kitchen rental and are ready to open a retail spot.

 

 

The Dream

We create all types of cruelty free treats from cakes and donuts to cannolis and stuffed cookies.  We make fun custom cakes for your themed parties, eye catching wedding dessert tables, and everyday treats to have just because. We are the creators of the Taccoli! Our popular cannoli dessert taco. Another favorite are our stuffed cookies, filled with fudge or biscoff. All these treats are tasty, but we want to continue growing. We want to offer fun drinks and smoothies, new desserts, and some comfort foods as well. There is so much room for growth in our new place. The possibilities are endless. Check out some of our mouthwatering menu ideas below!

Now that we have found a place to call home, we need to make some alterations and purchase some start up items. We have a detailed list below  of some of the major items we will need. We need things like a deep fryer and a hood system to keep creating our famous cannoli. There are also plenty of permits and licensing costs we will endure. Here is a layout of we hope our retail section will come together as. The current set up is very dated, but we will be using whatever we can to get up and running as soon as possible. We will likely need to add a waterline once we purchase the coffee machine, ice maker, and add a hand-washing sink. We will also need to hire an electrician to make some upgrades as well.

 

 

Perks Galore!

We have some amazing perks for you from a coffee club to cake decorating classes. We also have wedding and gift card discounts. There are one in a life time perks and some that are limited in quantity. We want you to be just as excited as we are! 

While we are hoping to meet our goal, we are happy with whatever we can achieve. Anything really does help, and if we don’t meet our goal we will still push through and source funding through loans. We are starting our goal at $19,000.00. It is a flex goal, so we graciously get to keep whatever we receive. Whether we bring in $100 or $40,000, we will be ever so thankful. If we happen to meet our first goal of $19,000. We will increase our goal to help reduce our $85,000 loan needs. 

You Matter

By contributing to this campaign, you are making a huge difference. Choosing vegan means you are putting an end to animal abuse, reducing pollution, and bettering your health. Every bite counts! 

I know together we can make a huge difference. Miss Vegan has seen a steady increase in orders. Our sales have more than tripled from out first year into our second. That is proof that taste is not compromised while choosing cruelty free. It’s so humbling! This business is hope for everyone and we will continue to stand for what we believe in one cake at a time. 

 

 

Below you will find a cost sheet of what we need to get started. There are many other costs such as an hvac system work, remodeling the retail area, hiring employees, and so on. We are just trying to get the bare minimum to get started. We have some funds saved we will be using for the above things. I know the bakery won't be an overnight adventure, but we have faith and drive to get it done. 

 

 

The Risks

Naturally with any new business there are risks. We are going to take this next move one step at a time to make sure we cover all our bases. We will start with visiting the town hall, the health department, and the state offices to make sure everything is done correctly and safely. We are planning for unexpected expenses by maintaining a small cushion of savings to keep up a float. We have plans to rent out kitchen space to other vegan start ups to help with out rent. We expect road blocks and hiccups, but we will look work past them. I am super determined and have been giving this company all of my energy since day one. 

 

Thank You!

Lastly, we want to thank you from the bottom of our hearts for being here, for reading this, for sharing this, and for contributing to the movement. If you aren’t able to take part in the perks, we would appreciate you sharing our cause. We couldn’t do this without you! I can’t wait to open our doors and stuff face with all of you! Thanks again.

story:
This is an effort to expand current production capabilities, and help raise money to donate to cancer research.

Chuck’s Pickles

My name is Chuck Woods and I love just about anything pickled (Okra and Herring are towards the bottom of my list, but mine are still delicious). I have years of experience in the food service industry, from my first job at the local Tastee-Freeze to Managing a District of 6 fast food stores, I’ve been everything from a fry cook to sous chef to General and District Manager. I also have vast experience in sales and marketing for different industries.

I am trying to fund the expansion of my pickling capabilities. I would like to get my pickled products out there for more people to enjoy, and yes, perhaps make a little money while doing it.

Unless this grows into something much larger than expected, this will not be a full-time job. That being said, if the masses dictate further expansion, I will accommodate. We will always produce small batch products, no artificial anything, just delicious !!!

What We Need & What You Get

I have set the funding goal at $2500. This will be used to cover all the fees to get a business license, health certificate, etc. so we can sell to the public. It will also allow us to purchase some or all of the following equipment:

  • Prep table & Shelving
  • Various pots, pans and containers
  • Water bath canner
  • Pressure canner
  • Jars, lids, etc.
  • Miscellaneous canning tools (funnels, lid lifters, jar lifters, etc.)
  • Produce, etc. to fulfill perks and create inventory

The perks offered will range from a small jar of garlic or ginger, T-Shirts & Hoodies to a year of “Chuck’s of the month” (a different pickled product each month). I will even have a perk where we will private label product for holiday gifts.

I am hoping to hit the $2500 and go far beyond !!! But if it happens to fall short, we will do what we can for expansion with what we get. ALL PERKS will be fulfilled no matter the amount raised. Contribute knowing you will receive your perk.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. You might not know which of your friends is a pickle aficionado, or would just want to help, so share with everyone !!!

Remember, please use the Indiegogo share tools! (This will help me keep people informed to progress, etc.)

Miscellaneous:

  • Contributor Coupons are good for all future regular priced product purchases. Online or at any event. (Not applicable for Chuck's of the Month, Clearance product or special combination offers. Does not apply to shipping charges)
  • If there is ever a product that you feel is not to your liking for any reason, you can exchange it for any equally priced item, or pay the difference for a higher priced item. Replacement shipping will be at no charge if applicable.
  • All shipped product MUST BE canned (unless additional amount paid for cold shipping). Local product can be canned or refrigerated items.

Sizes

  • Small - 4oz
  • Medium - 8oz
  • Large - 16oz (Pint)
  • X-Large - 32oz (Quart)
  • Gallon - 128oz (4 Quarts)
  • 3 Gallon - 384oz (18 Quarts)
  • 5.5 Gallon - 704oz (22 Quarts)
  • 30 Gallon and 55 Gallon batches available with prepaid advanced notice.

Let me know if you have any questions, thanks !!!

story:
Story 

Our mission is to support the preservation of the most volatile rain forests in Central America, by providing economic opportunities for local communities without the need for deforestation. With the help of the Rainforest Alliance and Forest Stewardship Council, we have started working directly with two communities in El Peten to extract organic sap from the Zapote tree - a large rainforest tree that grows in this region. We then use this sap or "chicle" to make the chewy part of our gum.. The trees are not hurt by this process and are only tapped every 4 years. Because these communities can live off of the sale of this unique sap, they no longer feel the pressure to cut down the rainforest to create farms.

We then purchase the sap and ship it in blocks to our small, organic-certified factory in El Segundo, California. There we grind up the blocks, add organic waxes, organic flavors, and organic sweeteners to make the world's ONLY organic sugar free chewing gum. 

In addition to using only organic ingredients, this product contains a unique blend of three organic sugar free sweeteners: organic Stevia, organic Monkfruit, and organic Erythritol. All three of these sweeteners come from organic, plant-based sources. The combination of these unique ingredients helps to remove bacteria from your teeth and strengthen your tooth enamel.

What people are saying about us

 

FAST COMPANY, MARCH 2018: “Wild Gum works with the Rainforest Alliance to preserve the tree sap it uses, and promotes growth and fair trade in local communities, supporting economic growth across Latin America.”

How is this different from other gums

98% of gum products in the USA are made with a synthetic plastic named Polyisobutylene or “PIB.” PIB is a refined form of petroleum that is manufactured in a 4-stack oil refinery and made into plastic-like pellets. These PIB pellets are then used by the world’s leading gum brands as a main ingredient in gumbase - the chewy part of the gum. Can you believe it?

The reason why this ingredient is not listed in the ingredient statement is because the chewing gum industry successfully lobbied the FDA to not be required to disclose this ingredient. As a result, the only labeling requirement for all of these synthetic ingredients in chewing gum is the word “gumbase." That means, we really don't know what we're chewing. 

 

And unfortunately most gums that claim to be natural - also use PIB in their gumbase. In other words, most natural gums are not natural! This is why we developed an Organic Certified gum - so there is no question that ALL of the ingredients in Wild Gum are truly organic-certified and from nature.

What we've done so far

It took us nearly 3 years and many failed trials to develop an organic gum with a great texture and flavor. While we were working on the development, we partnered with the Rainforest Alliance to meet with local communities in El Peten, Guatemala and finally signed agreements with them to harvest the sap. Then we set up a supply chain to ship the ingredients to the US and worked with organic certifiers to certify the sap at the source - right in the rainforest! Our product has also been accepted into UNFI - the largest US Natural Foods distributor and we have started reviewing samples with leading natural retailers. Everything is now set up and ready to go!  

(above) Instagram image from a Whole Foods Forrager

What we need

Now we need funding to purchase enough raw ingredients from El Peten to make commercial quantities and to begin to sell Wild Gum in the US and EU.  Our goal is to sell Wild Gum first into the Retail Natural Foods channel in both the US and EU regions - as we’ve had a number of requests already. In addition, we will also focus on Mass, Club, Premium Grocery & Drug channels, select apparel retail, co-working spaces, and other lifestyle/outdoor retailers.

About Us

We are a number of ex-consumer product marketing and supply chain people that decided that we want to help make the world a better place through our efforts. We weren’t sure in the beginning what it would be, so we started looking. Then we discovered the opportunity to help create an economic incentive to keep the rainforest intact. This was exciting! We still did the work on the side of our days jobs for a while, but after finally perfecting the product and setting up the agreement with the communities in El Peten, then we went full time. Now we are ready to officially launch Wild Gum and need your help!
story_txt: Story Our mission is to support the preservation of the most volatile rain forests in Central America, by providing economic opportunities for local communities without the need for deforestation. With the help of the Rainforest Alliance and Forest Stewardship Council, we have started working directly with two communities in El Peten to extract organic sap from the Zapote tree - a large rainforest tree that grows in this region. We then use this sap or "chicle" to make the chewy part of our gum.. The trees are not hurt by this process and are only tapped every 4 years. Because these communities can live off of the sale of this unique sap, they no longer feel the pressure to cut down the rainforest to create farms.We then purchase the sap and ship it in blocks to our small, organic-certified factory in El Segundo, California. There we grind up the blocks, add organic waxes, organic flavors, and organic sweeteners to make the world's ONLY organic sugar free chewing gum. In addition to using only organic ingredients, this product contains a unique blend of three organic sugar free sweeteners: organic Stevia, organic Monkfruit, and organic Erythritol. All three of these sweeteners come from organic, plant-based sources. The combination of these unique ingredients helps to remove bacteria from your teeth and strengthen your tooth enamel.What people are saying about us FAST COMPANY, MARCH 2018: “Wild Gum works with the Rainforest Alliance to preserve the tree sap it uses, and promotes growth and fair trade in local communities, supporting economic growth across Latin America.”How is this different from other gums98% of gum products in the USA are made with a synthetic plastic named Polyisobutylene or “PIB.” PIB is a refined form of petroleum that is manufactured in a 4-stack oil refinery and made into plastic-like pellets. These PIB pellets are then used by the world’s leading gum brands as a main ingredient in gumbase - the chewy part of the gum. Can you believe it?The reason why this ingredient is not listed in the ingredient statement is because the chewing gum industry successfully lobbied the FDA to not be required to disclose this ingredient. As a result, the only labeling requirement for all of these synthetic ingredients in chewing gum is the word “gumbase." That means, we really don't know what we're chewing.  And unfortunately most gums that claim to be natural - also use PIB in their gumbase. In other words, most natural gums are not natural! This is why we developed an Organic Certified gum - so there is no question that ALL of the ingredients in Wild Gum are truly organic-certified and from nature.What we've done so farIt took us nearly 3 years and many failed trials to develop an organic gum with a great texture and flavor. While we were working on the development, we partnered with the Rainforest Alliance to meet with local communities in El Peten, Guatemala and finally signed agreements with them to harvest the sap. Then we set up a supply chain to ship the ingredients to the US and worked with organic certifiers to certify the sap at the source - right in the rainforest! Our product has also been accepted into UNFI - the largest US Natural Foods distributor and we have started reviewing samples with leading natural retailers. Everything is now set up and ready to go!  (above) Instagram image from a Whole Foods ForragerWhat we needNow we need funding to purchase enough raw ingredients from El Peten to make commercial quantities and to begin to sell Wild Gum in the US and EU.  Our goal is to sell Wild Gum first into the Retail Natural Foods channel in both the US and EU regions - as we’ve had a number of requests already. In addition, we will also focus on Mass, Club, Premium Grocery & Drug channels, select apparel retail, co-working spaces, and other lifestyle/outdoor retailers.About UsWe are a number of ex-consumer product marketing and supply chain people that decided that we want to help make the world a better place through our efforts. We weren’t sure in the beginning what it would be, so we started looking. Then we discovered the opportunity to help create an economic incentive to keep the rainforest intact. This was exciting! We still did the work on the side of our days jobs for a while, but after finally perfecting the product and setting up the agreement with the communities in El Peten, then we went full time. Now we are ready to officially launch Wild Gum and need your help!

story:
Our Story

Our story begins with the dream of our grandparents, Pop Pop and Nana. They had a dream to share Nana's amazing cooking skills with the world while bringing their family together. Every morning at 4 a.m. Nana would walk from her Sherwood Park home to The Donut Hole and commit to baking donuts with her son, and every morning they would open the doors with cheer. She believed that her handmade pastries, signature Philadelphia street food, and smile would brighten up anyone's day. And it did for 21 years! Today, it has been our mission to continue her legacy by providing our guests with the love and warmth she gave everyone who walked through her doors.

The rebirth of The Donut Hole has been a grass roots effort from its' inception two years ago, 3 minority women with the drive and the passion to bring a Huntsville staple back better than ever. Two years ago we opened The Donut Hole with less than 50,000 and funded it all by our own hands. No investors-- just relying on the a small community loan fund and contributions from friends and family.

--The strength from this unity allowed us to open our tiny 10 seat donut eatery in the middle of Huntsville, Alabama. This opportunity allowed us to happily serve our community morning after morning with our unique donuts and east coast street food. 

picture provide by: https://cosmopolitancornbread.com/the-donut-hole/

In our first year The Donut Hole was nominated by the Huntsville Chamber of Commerce for Emerging Business of the Year, and Best Women Owned Business of The Year. 

We currently maintain a 4.9 star rating on Facebook, Yelp, and Trip Advisor, for the quality of our product and stellar customer service.

picture provide by: https://cosmopolitancornbread.com/the-donut-hole/

In the two years we have been open, we have been truly blessed and we are so grateful and appreciative of our customers, fans, and visitors. We could not have made it this far without the continuous support of our community.

--Now, we are calling on our community and those who believe in the dream of entrepreneurship, a thriving local economy, and equal opportunity for hard working people to help us sustain one of the last remaining Huntsville gems. 

picture provide by: https://cosmopolitancornbread.com/the-donut-hole/

Our Challenges

Currently, The Donut Hole is facing the threat of closure. Mainly due to a corporate giant that moved next door and took over most of the availability for our customers to park and patronize our business.  In our first year, we hit record sales being the only "sweet treat eatery" within miles and had the space to accommodate all of our daily traffic. However, in the winter of 2017 a sweet treat corporate giant was built right next to us and seized our additional parking lot, cutting off a large majority of our parking and only allowing us three spaces to accommodate customers at a time. Because of this, we have the need to move to a new and bigger location so we can accommodate all customers from far and wide.  

In addition, after moving into our current building, it became clear that our building was not equipped to sustain our electrical needs, causing frequent problems and outages with our day to day operations.

Despite our challenges, we remain dedicated to continuing to provide great service and quality in our food. With your help, we can not only continue grow locally, but nationally as well.

Our Goals

Throughout the past year, we have had great support of family and friends to help keep the dream of our business alive. However, with no investor, we now have to call on our greater community to help us. 

We are aiming for $100,000 to continue The Donut Hole's legacy. This goal will cover moving expenses, build out cost of a new Downtown location, and a vendor truck which would make our products more accessible to everyone in North Alabama.

We are humbly asking for the help of our community on a local and national level because our greatest goal is to expand into an even bigger and better Donut Hole, a Donut Hole everyone can enjoy and have access to.  

We believe that The Donut Hole is not just about our family, it is about the Huntsville family at large. It has so much meaning to the citizens of Huntsville, as many families who frequented our Grandparents' shop take pride in bringing their children and grandchildren to experience the nostalgic pleasure of the longest running family donut eatery in town. We love our customers, we love our business, and we love the family and friends we have developed over the years and we want to continue to be there for the community for years to come. Our Grandparents' legacy lives on in The Donut Hole, and it gives us something to give our children, giving them a chance at the American dream. 

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

SUPPORT THE CAMPAIGN

We welcome you to support this effort at any level. Every dollar will help go to help us work toward saving The Donut Hole. 

$100,000 is the minimum cost we need to relocate and cover operating cost, but we would like to exceed that number in order to cover any additional unexpected operating cost. So please share and like this campaign and help us breathe life into The Donut Hole.

You can also purchase a "Donut Forget About Us" Limited edition t-shirt or our Classic "Donut Worry Be Happy" t-shirt and all proceeds will go to support our efforts.

STOP BY AND SEE US

The Donut Hole relies on the support of the community. Although, we are a small batch bakery, you can place orders for your office, meetings, school or even wedding! We are open six days a week and are known not only for our Donuts, but for our lunch items as well. We have authentic Philly Cheesesteaks and Hoagies, so bring your friends for lunch! Let us know you appreciate our small business by making us your preferred choice!

SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN AND TAG US ON SOCIAL MEDIA

Shout it from the roof tops! Please share this with anyone you know who values local businesses, entrepreneurship and quality in the food industry. Two years ago we opened The Donut Hole with the help of you, the community and our family and friends, and we are calling on you now to help us put in the same ground work to save our business.

We thank you all and God bless your families!

Love,

Alimah, Nicole, Teneshia, and the Green EL family.

story:
Short Summary

Our food is delicious, satisfying, highly nourishing, and is also Gluten Free and Vegan. We want to help people enjoy delicious food, be healthy and feel good about their food choices. We believe that when people discover how amazing the food tastes, the decision to eat responsibly will be easy.

The Impact

The area around the cafe is pretty sorely in need of allergen-friendly & plant-based options, so we're excited to start serving the community with healthy delicious food!

Risks & Challenges

As countless friends and associates have pointed out, the restaurant/cafe business can be pretty brutal. We understand that it will take an immense amount of work, perseverance, patience, and grace to make Celest Cafe successful and we welcome the challenge! Your financial support is most appreciated, but your encouragement and social support is just as important! Please share this campaign with anyone whom you feel may be interested in this type of project, and please come see us at the cafe when we open!

Other Ways You Can Help

Your support in sharing our story and helping us reach more people in our community is incredibly helpful! Please share this story on your social media pages and text/email the link to anyone you know who is: Plant Based, Gluten Free, Vegan, Vegetarian, Dairy Free, Egg Free, Soy Free, Super Awesome, A Foodie, Interested in Higher Consciousness, or Lives in Seattle!

story:
It's likely that most of you will already know me. If not, let me introduce myself. My name is Ben and I own Lassen Traditional Cider. My drive to get into making cider commercially comes from a long history of fermentation projects and making cider at home and a belief that I could do better than many other commonly available ciders. I've been selling my cider commercially for just over a year. I have a strong commitment to making what I refer to as real cider. To me, this means traditional, dry, heritage-style cider that's a completely different product than what many people think of when they think of cider. My cider making style is a simple, non-interventionist approach- good apples and time- hands off, letting nature take its course. The most important thing to me is the fruit. I don't buy whatever apples I can get, or worse, mass produced juice or concentrate. I seek out varieties that make good cider. My biggest lesson from making cider at home was that some apples make amazing cider, and others, not so much. My focus is on using American heirloom varieties that have a rich tradition in cider making. My mainstays are Newtown Pippin, King David, Winesap, and Arkansas Black. These are not necessarily the super tannic bittersweet or bittersharp apples used in traditional European ciders, but what they lack in tannins, they make up for in aromatics. Indeed, once a bite is taken out of a fully ripe heirloom apple, it can be difficult to go back to eating some of the more common supermarket dessert varieties that dominate store shelves. Most younger people have never heard the names Newtown Pippin and Winesap, but ask an old-timer and they get a gleam in their eye reminiscing about when they would go get some of those fresh off the tree at their local orchard.

After I find this high quality fruit, I haul it to my cidery where I press it and put it directly into neutral wine barrels. They were used for wine for a period of 3-5 years and most of the tannins in the oak have been leached out by the wine. The cider, unsulfited is wild fermented to complete dryness in the barrels for up to three months. The native yeast on the fruit, brought in from the orchard, combined with whatever resident yeasts are in the air or on the cider equipment are allowed to perform the fermentation. Primary fermentation is mostly complete within a month then it's allowed to sit on the lees for a couple more months, picking up additional barrel flavor and starting the aging process. The cider is then racked out of the barrels, blended, mixed with a small amount of fresh apple juice and bottled. The fresh juice gives the yeast one last kick, where their activity picks back up again in the bottle just enough to start a secondary fermentation for natural carbonation, or bottle conditioning, similar to the methode champenoise. The cider is neither filtered or pasteurized. Being a live product, it tends to continue evolving throughout the year, and will mature just fine for years.

High end craft cider is still a new experience for many people. When most folks take a sip of my cider they typically comment how different it is from most ciders they've had. The sad thing is that a lot of cheap 6 pack ciders taste more like apple juice than cider. These "cider coolers" are not what I'd call cider. Does wine taste like grape juice? Of course not! The fact is, high quality cider has the potential to expand into a huge market. Many people are starting to make high end cider, and in 3-5 years there will be many options for this level of artisanal cider. The word "craft" gets thrown around a lot these days by cideries and breweries. But what I'm talking about is true craft. People are planting cider and heirloom apple varieties and the world of cider will change greatly in the near future.

I've been selling my cider all over Northern California, filling up my car with cases and personally delivering them. While many people have yet to figure out what real cider is, I have found a reasonable amount of success and notoriety. I've received awards in the Great Lakes International Cider Competition and the California Cider Competition, and my Newtown Pippin cider was recently named a Good Food award finalist, a competition with a rigorous vetting process for producers making high quality products using responsible methods.

In summary, I'd like to be able to position my company to be able to grow and establish itself as a regional brand. As of now, I'm still small enough that I can still self distribute, but I'd like to grow my production enough where I can justify going through a distributor and selling outside of the state of California. To be able to increase production, I need a bigger press. The press I have now is rather small. My production this year will be a little over 2000 gallons and it took a lot of work to get there. The amount I'd need for a larger pressing system will run around $40,000. I'm doing this campaign to raise money for part of that expense. I will be taking out a loan for the remainder. If you can help out, you'll be rewarded greatly. The perks are all useful, stylish, and functional. For those of you who've never tried my cider, consider buying some as a perk. Help make Lassen Traditional Cider a success! Together we can put cider on a track to where the wine industry is!

Please help spread the word and forward on to other people who might be interested! Thanks for reading and I'm sincerely grateful if you decide to contribute.
